episode.title: Nixon v. Administrator of General Services

section.heading: Argument of Herbert J. Miller, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments first this morning in 75-1605, Nixon against the Administrator of General Services Administration.
Mr. Miller, you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

This case involves the first time in the 200-year history of our republic that Congress has seen fit to enact legislation seizing the papers, five-and-a-half years of the administration of a former President of the United States.
The core of this case, if the Court please, involves tapes, some 5,000 hours of tapes, which contain conversations by the former President which deal with a broad spectrum.
They range from political discussions to discussion with his aides as to what steps and decisions should be made by the Presidency.

It also deals with matters highly personal, such as conversations with his wife, conversations with his daughter immediately prior to her marriage and also conversations with his counsel, with his physician and with his clergymen.

One problem with this case in realizing the impact and the effect of the legislation is that involved is 42 million documents as an estimate; but really, the core of this case are the tapes, which were seized by Section 101 of the Act in question, and the balance of the Presidential material.

I would like at the outset to emphasize to the Court that Section 101(a), which seizes the tape recordings, has no qualifying language which indicates that the seizure is directed solely to Presidential material or the like.
There is a wholesale seizure of those tapes.
Section 101(b) talks in terms of seizing all of the balance of the Presidential materials.
These materials which represent the actions, both personal and private, of the former President over a five-and-a-half-year period are currently in the control of the United States.
When Mr. Nixon left the White House, he left directions that these materials were to be forwarded to him.
This direction was countermanded at the request of the Special Prosecutor, and subsequently the legislation in question was enacted.

And I emphasize that this legislation, which was enacted and which seized the tapes, which seized all other Presidential materials, was enacted in haste and was enacted without a Congressional hearing.
The impact of this statute on the former President, and indeed on the Presidency itself, is very clear.

First, under Section 102(d) of the Act, access is given to any Agency or Department of the United States to have access to the tape recordings, to have access to any of the Presidential materials of the former President for any lawful Government purpose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, subject to the regulations which the Administrators shall issue.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Subject to the regulations which have been enacted and have been enforced since January of 1975, if the Court please.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Miller, at this point, you are just factually describing the effect of the Congressional legislation, right?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
The regulations which have been adapted permit and confirm that the Agencies or Departments of the United States do have access to these tapes for any lawful Government purpose.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are the regulations in the material has been submitted to us, Mr. Miller?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I believe that they are in the appendix, if the Court please.
If not, I can supply the Court with the citation.
Regulations are Part 105-63 of Title 41, Code of Federal Regulations.
The additional impact of this statue is very clear.

First of all, it directs and it has been accomplished a seizure of five-and-one-half years of a man’s entire material, whether they deal with the actions as President, whether they deal with his actions as political leader of his party or whether they deal with actions as a father and as a husband.
These records have been seized, and they have stayed seized ever since the statute was enacted.
Mr. Nixon has not had access to these records except as he has sent someone 3,000 miles to his home to have access to these particular records.
The purpose, if the Court please, of Section 104 of the Presidential Materials Act is that these documents or specified portions thereon will be made public.

That is what Congress enacted, that is what Congress intended, and that is subject only to the adoption of regulations by the Administrator of General Services, which must be approved, or can be disapproved, if I may correct myself, by one House of the Congress.
Those regulations are not in effect, one of the reasons being that they have been proposed, that they have been disapproved, they have been withdrawn.

And if the Court please, the status of those regulations is in a very confused state at the moment; but the ultimate purpose, in addition to seizing these records, was that those certain matters in those records would be extracted by the United States and be made public.

The most intrusive part of the statute in question is that it has authorized the Archivist of the United States, some hundreds is what the plans are, to go through all of these records word by word, all of the tape recordings, whether they involve conversations with his wife, with his daughter, whether they involve conversations dealing with his political decisions, whether they involve decisions dealing with foreign affairs, whether they involve his decisions with respect to domestic matters.
It is a wholesale and grand search in any sense of the word.
That is the immediate impact of this statute.
The Constitution of the United States vests in a President of the United States the Executive power of the United States.

It is that Executive power which this act impacts directly, because it permits access to, review of and ultimately publication of matters which are totally privileged and presumptively privileged under the decision of this Court in United States versus Nixon.

Without the confidentiality that a President of the United States has and expects and has expected for over 200 years until this legislation, this Court has ruled that the President and his aides cannot receive the plain, unvarnished and candid advice that he has the right to expect to receive and must receive for the proper operation of the Presidency of the United States.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Insofar as that is a separation-of-powers argument, Mr. Miller, the act applies only to former President Nixon.
There is no reason to think that Congress is going to pass an act that is generally applicable to Presidents in the future, is there?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I know of no reason to expect that to happen except that as a second half of the statute in question, a Presidential or a Governmental Materials Commission has been formed and is about to render a report, in which they will make recommendations as to whether Congress should enact legislation which deals with the records and materials of future Presidencies and also with the third branch, the Judiciary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So there would be time enough, I take it, to confront anything Congress does in response to that report when it does it.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: It would be time enough as to the impact on existing Presidencies; but this act has an impact on the operation of the Presidency already, because people in the White House, whether it be the White House of President Ford or President Carter, recognized that it is possible if this law is sustained on a constitutional basis that the statute will be enacted which will deprive them of their private papers and the papers of their Presidency, because if you can do it in one instance, there is no reason why you cannot do it in another.

If the separation-of-powers principle permits Congress to enact legislation seizing every scrap of material for five-and-a half years or six months or three months, as the case is now, of the operations of a President of the United States, I say that that act is totally unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But there is not any impairment of any presently conducted Executive function by the act, where there was in Myers’ or Humphrey’s Executive.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I say that there is.
The act does not apply to any Administrations except that of former President Nixon.

I say that the principle is a restraining effect on successive Presidencies, because when those Presidents are conferring with their aides, they are doing so with the understanding that possibly all of those deliberations and conversations may be made public by subsequent legislative acts.
So I say there is an immediate impact.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would you still object to this act if on its face it simply says -- and maybe this one does -- that anything that would threaten the Executive privilege or anything that would threaten to reveal the kinds of papers that might inhibit free and open discussion between the President and his aides will be destroyed or that they will never be made public?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: If I understand your question, the legislation would simply say that the records would never be made public?
I would say --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not the records, but that they will be sorted out.
Surely you do not say that every piece of paper out of this entire straw stack of papers is privileged.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I do not, absolutely not; a substantial portion.
The question of these records --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let's assume, then, you could divide them into two parts and without any idea of what the relative volume of each part might be; but assume that they had been divided into two parts, and one part is privileged; and suppose the act said once you get them divided into two parts and you know what the privileged information is, that will not be made public.
Will that satisfy you or not, your separation-of-powers argument?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: It would satisfy the separation of powers to this extent: it would stop the intrusion by archivists and others into these papers, because as privileged, they could not be reviewed by third parties.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if things are intermixed, somebody is going to have to review them and divide them.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: If somebody has to review them or divide them, that is one of the very issues that goes to the basis of the Fourth Amendment argument, if the Court please.
But let's assume arguendo that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why doesn't it go to your separation-of-powers argument that not only are some things privileged, but only the President should decide which are, or the former President?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the former President can determine which are privileged.
This Court has already decided it would determine what are privileged occasions and has so decided.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, is anything contemplated under this act necessarily going to prevent the former President from examining these papers and giving his opinion as to which are privileged?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Nothing will prevent the former President from doing that.
He is given a right of access from 3,000 miles away, if he desires to come here to review them.

The thing that would prevent him from reviewing and determining all of them would be the substantial burden involved, because it does represent five-and-a-half years of the Presidency of the United States.

But if I understand the decisions of this Court in the past in terms of the concept of separation of power, the deliberation of each branch, whether it be the Judiciary, whether it be the Congress of the United States or whether it be the Presidency of the United States, the deliberations of each branch are for and within the sole domain and the determinations of each of those branches, the reason being stated very simply that if one branch of Government can intervene into the deliberative process of the other, then truly there has been an interference and a breach of the concept of separation of power, because the ultimate decision and how you make decisions is solely within the discretion and the determination of each of the branches.
Congress cannot pass --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Suppose you had a Congressional Committee thinking about legislating about this subject, and it subpoenaed some of these papers.
Do you think those objections on the part of the Executive branch, even assuming it was an incumbent President, would just be uniformly sustained?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Justice Rehnquist, I would say this.

If the documents subpoenaed were documents which dealt with or tape recordings which revealed the decision-making process, the conferences that were had, the positions put forth by the aide to the President, that those documents are presumptively privileged.

And in fact, you may recall that the Senate of the United States or a Committee thereof did, in fact, attempt to subpoena several of the tape recordings, and the Court of Appeals below held that no sufficient showing had been made to breach the presumptive privilege.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Have not Presidents all the way back to President Washington declined to give to Congress as distinguished from the courts, declined to give to Congress certain papers under the doctrine of Executive privilege?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: There has, if the Court please, been a long history and tradition.
The first instance that I know of where the President of the United States refused to grant information requested by the Congress was George Washington.
Congress strongly requested that he supply information as to what his Presidential instructions were to the advisors that were in the process of negotiating the Jay Treaty.
President Washington refused to do so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you would be making the same argument and are making it with respect to a subpoena directed to our conference notes.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely, if the Court please, absolutely.
The deliberative process cannot be invaded by one branch by either of the other two.
That has to be an established basis of the entire concept of the separation of power, because if you can invade the deliberative process, you can control its result.
The reason it is important, particularly in terms of the Presidency, it is very difficult to understand how the Office of the President works.
It is not, as most people assume, an office of record.
All of the Presidential final decisions upon which this Court will act, upon which Congressional action can be taken, are filed in various Departments.
Treaties are filed with the State Department.
Pardons are filed with the Department of Justice.
You go through the various Presidential decisions, and those become a part of the permanent files of the various Department of Government which is involved in the decisions.
The Presidential Office is not an office of record.
It is an office whereby it is determined how a decision is to be made, and then those decisions are forwarded on.

A second broad reason or attack on this statute, and one which I do not think there can be any justifiable defense to, and that is that this Congressional action is as clear and is as grand and as wholesale a violation of the protected privacy of the Fourth Amendment of the United States as can be envisioned.

To enact legislation, as Congress has done, which directs that five-and-a-half years of a man’s paper, personal and private, as well as Presidential, be seized by a Government agent or Government agency; that those records be made available forthwith to any Agency or Department of the Federal Government; that they be made available immediately, subject to any rights or privileges, which may be raised for judicial subpoena; and that while over 100 archivists, accompanied by lawyers, technicians and secretaries, will have a right to review word by word five-and-one-half years of a man’s life is to me absolutely clear, as clear a violation of the Fourth Amendment as one can imagine.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would not suggest, would you, that this stands on the same footing as if Congress had decided to take five-and-a-half years of your papers, you being a private citizen.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: The distinction with respect to Mr. Nixon’s personal papers does not exist.
His personal papers are as personal to him as mine are to me.

And I say that the Congress does not have a right to enact legislation directing the head of GSA to take five years, or indeed six months, of my personal records, and they had no such right with respect to the personal records of the former President.
The cases of this Court which --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does this act now authorize any other Government officials who wants to look at any part of this collection of papers give him the right to do so?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Under Section 102(d) of the act, any Agency or Department of the Federal Government has the right to immediate access to any parts of these papers, be they the tape recordings, be they Presidential papers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even if anyone who was halfway fair-minded would concede that this is a purely private piece of paper, he may see it?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: The only caveat is that the intrusion must be for lawful Government use.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what does that mean?
How can something purely private and personal be of lawful Government use?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: It cannot be, if the Court please.
It absolutely cannot be, and yet this is what the statute directs, that these personal --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Doesn't the statute say "subject to the regulations"?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think it does.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Well, it is subject to the regulations to be enacted by Section 103.
If the Court please, those regulations have been adopted and were adopted in January of 1975.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And they are not in the record before us.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I assumed that they were, but perhaps they are not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, those have been adopted, and those are not the ones that were rejected by Congress?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: They were not, no.
The ones rejected by Congress --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All right, so they are not rejected, so they must be in the Federal Registry.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, they are, absolutely.
The regulations rejected by Congress were pursuant to Section 104(a) of the act, which required that the Administrator adopt regulations to make public.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the regulations permitting access by the Government officials, do they have restrictions in them?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: They have has sections permitting … what these regulations do is, they track the exact language of the statute, and they give access to any Agency or Department of the United States to have access to these records.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does Mr. Nixon or his representatives get notice any time any Government official wants to look at any part of it or not?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Under the regulations in the Federal Register promulgated pursuant to Section 103, any archival intrusion, i.e., any time an archivist goes in, there is a provision that the Counsel to the President of the United States -- in this instance, President Carter -- will be notified and given the right to review what happens, and notice is given to the former President.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So if some other Department of the Government wanted to for some supposedly lawful purpose examine some of the papers, Mr. Nixon would have notice of it?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: He would have notice under Section 103 of the regulations, yes.
And whether he would be given notice under the regulations ultimately to be adopted under Section 104, we would have to wait for those regulations.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the act contain any penalties for disclosure by any employee of the many employees who would have access to this?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: None whatsoever.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ah, of course.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: None whatsoever.

In fact, with respect to archival intrusion, if these hundred archivists with lawyers and what-have-you, go through these personal tape recordings and other conversations without a warrant, making a cert, they have an obligation to turn over to the Department of Justice, if they find anything that might warrant further investigations on the way; so that this is, in truth, an absolute truth, a cert followed by a seizure, which I strongly submit is totally violative of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do the regulations deal with the question of impermissible disclosure?
Suppose some clerk or any one of the many people dealing with this screening process makes a Xerox copy and sells it to someone.
Do you say that there is no penalty at all on that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: There are general regulations adopted which apply to members and employees of the General Services Administration, if the Court please, and those regulations generally forbid making available to the public.
There are also standard statutes in the Title XVIII, which prohibits Government officers from making available certain types of information.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But no criminal penalty.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: In those there would be, but not on the GSA regulations, which have broad applicability here.
At this time, if the Court please, Mr. Lewin will present the balance today.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Miller, before you sit down, could I ask one question?
Is there any issue presented with respect to the materials that Mr. Nixon took out of the Government custody?
A footnote in the Government's brief points out that some materials are in his custody, and I would think Section 101(b)(1) may read on those materials.
Is there any issue with respect to that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Yes; in fact, there has been no issue raised yet, because the Administrator of GSA has not undertaken the reasonable efforts required of him by Section 102 to reach out and take those records.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what I really wanted to ask.
There has been no attempt to enforce 101(b)(1) yet.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Not as to documents in Mr. Nixon’s possession; but if they are, then they are going to reach the Dictabelt and his oral diaries that he dictated at the end of every day, most of which are also a part of the tape recordings I had mentioned, because when he dictated his diary at the end of the day as to what transpired, how his day went, his most personal thoughts, those, too, become a part of the tape recordings that I mentioned here, as well as being on the Dictabelt.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the record tell us why there has been no effort to enforce that section?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: There has been no record, because in effect there has been a stay of any action up to this date.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Lewin?

turn.speaker: nathan_lewin
turn.label: Mr. Nathan Lewin
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

I would like in the time available to me to speak to the constitutional standards for evaluating the statute under the three arguments that we presented in our brief, because we think the standards are different and the District Court really applied a balancing test, which is inappropriate to two of the three separate arguments that are made in our brief.

But just momentarily before going to that question, and I think in some way it does relate to the application of a balancing test to the question of separation of powers, I believe Justices White and Rehnquist did raise the question of whether this statute is not in some way constitutionally sufficient, because it either applies only retrospectively to one President or because it might by its application really be read to give President Nixon an opportunity to challenge whenever there is some violation of Presidential confidentiality.

And we think that that overlooks the basic presumption that underlies our separation-of-powers argument, which is that the notion of separation of powers, as applied to statements and advice given to a President in confidence, is really a proposition that acts in futuro; in other words, only if a presumption of confidentially exists do existing advisers speak frankly, just as existing law clerks will speak frankly to Justices of this Court, because they know that their advice is given in confidence, in the same way, the near possibility that a statute may be enacted retrospectively to apply to President Ford or Carter or the possibility that a President may be put, with regard to every individual piece of paper or every advice, to the burden of litigating it at some future time and asserting his Presidential privilege is sufficient to impede the free flow of communication.
And that is precisely why we think this Court adapted the rule of presumption of confidentiality and stated it as strongly as it did in United States versus Nixon.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the analogy here, Mr. Lewin, is a former Justice of this Court comes in and objects to a law that Congress has passed, and all the present Justices say, "We don't see any problem with it".

turn.speaker: nathan_lewin
turn.label: Mr. Nathan Lewin
turn.text: Well, I think that the present Justices' law clerks, even if all the present Justices said there was no problem, I think the Justices would agree that the present law clerks and their own relations with their law clerks would be substantially affected by the existence, and indeed by the judicial imprimatur, put upon such as statute.

It would mean with regard to your own law clerks that after you left the Court, a similar statute might be enacted; and even though you might think today that it does not concern or does not relate to the way you operate your office, the successor to that seat might differ with that view.

And consequently, we have argued in our brief and we believe that no present occupant of a position such as the Presidency or such as an Article III position, on this Court or on any Federal District Court or indeed any Congressman may not permanently waive those elements which are necessarily incident to the proper functioning of that office, even if he agrees with it today, and that, we think, is the basic deficiency in the argument that is made both by the Solicitor General and by the private Appellees when they say that this is not a separation-of-powers case.

Indeed it is in every sense, because the issue of confidentiality of Presidential communications, irrespective of what the president incumbent may think of that confidentiality, is a question which is decided in this case for all time and will therefore bind future Presidents, who may disagree with what Mr. Carter believes or what Mr. Ford believes, if indeed Mr. Ford did believe that it made no difference.

We submit that to the extent that there was really any indication of what Presidential policy was, the agreement, which is in the record, the Nixon-Sampson Depository Agreement, indicates that President Ford believed that for purposes of ongoing Government business, which is really, I think, the principle thing that the Appellees are relying on in this case, which is not so much historical interest, although that is talked about in the legislation; but in the briefs before this Court, heavy emphasis is placed on ongoing Government business, and President Ford was entirely satisfied with an arrangement between himself and his predecessor under which he would be given access.
And we think that is what 200 years of history have shown, that that is satisfied by arrangements between succeeding Presidents.

The Congress had before it no record of extensive disagreement or of extensive situations which presented problems with regard to future Presidents obtaining records that their predecessors may have had, and indeed the Appellees have only plucked out of an entire 200-year history basically, I think, one two or at most three instances where there was a request which was honored, and indeed only one situation where there was a lower-level request which was not honored as between successor Presidents, and that was not by the President in office, but by a very low-ranking individual who would made a call to John Eisenhower and asked him whether he might have a paper and where Mr. Eisenhower said, “We will have that request made by the President himself”, the request was never made.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am a little puzzled by your repeated reference to the judicial area, the communications between law clerks and Justices and judges.
What about communications as among the Justices and judges themselves?
Would you think they are a lesser or greater privilege?

turn.speaker: nathan_lewin
turn.label: Mr. Nathan Lewin
turn.text: I think the privilege is, in terms of policy reasons, I think it is even greater.

I have only analogized it in terms of law clerks, because with this Court, and I believe with every individual judge who sits, the analog, I would think, to the President, who is at very top of the Executive structure, who is the Chief Executive, are the subordinates to that President; and consequently, in order to provide the closest analogy, I tried to compare it to those who worked for Justices of the Court.

But certainly to the extent that there are internal Judicial Branch discussions, which by approving this kind of statute this Court would be saying Congress might very well reach those kinds of papers, I think the very same problem exists, and indeed that very report which Mr. Miller was referring to, I think, was suggesting that there would be restraints placed on the ability of Justices to destroy papers, which the leading Justices in the history of this Court down to very modern times have assumed they had certainly the right to do in terms of internal papers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Previous Presidents have received substantial tax benefits by virtue of claimed ownership, have they not, of their papers?

turn.speaker: nathan_lewin
turn.label: Mr. Nathan Lewin
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, and we think that that is a totally separate problem.

We are not here today arguing anything, really, that goes to what ownership rights may be except to the extent that they bear on Mr. Nixon’s expectations on what the proper constitutional rule is, on how the country is operated.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does it bear on your bill-of-attainder arguments?

turn.speaker: nathan_lewin
turn.label: Mr. Nathan Lewin
turn.text: Yes, and if I could just in the very few minutes I have, I would like to speak on that bill-of-attainder argument, because I think that here, too, the court below has mistaken the proper constitutional standard.

Congress could have enacted a law if it thought on the basis of its various investigations and the discussions of the floor of the Senate that Mr. Nixon was an unreliable custodian of documents, it could have enacted a law that said any unreliable custodian of documents, be it a President, Vice President or any other Federal officer, may have those documents taken away from him if it is shown in a judicial forum that he is an unreliable custodian; and there could be temporary retraining orders, preliminary injunctions, every remedy that this statute provides.
What does this statute do more than that statute does?
It makes Congress the fact-finder, and that is exactly what this Court has said in a series of cases, culminating with United States versus Brown, that Congress may not be the fact-finder.
And why may Congress not be the fact finder?
Because in that case, the party against whom it finds the facts has no judicial trial, no counsel to represent him, no opportunity to cross-examine the witnesses or present witnesses in his defense.
The entire range of what judicial trial is all about is obviated.
In this case, Congress held not a single hearing on this statute.
It did hold hearings on a predecessor statute looking to the question of Federal officials' records generally, but not on this statute.

There was no opportunity other than statements made on the floor of the Senate, just assertions, which were picked up by the District Court in this case, to the notion that Mr. Nixon is an unreliable custodian for historical purposes.
And we submit that what the bill-of-attainder clause says is that the Congress may not make that ultimate factual finding, and here it has done it, it has mentioned Richard Nixon by name.

Congress did not even dare do anything in the Brown case and this Court has mentioned that certainly Archie Brown has been mentioned by name as someone who could not occupy a union office; that would be a bill of attainder.
And here, Congress has said Richard Nixon is the person who cannot decide which papers are confidential and which papers are not.
That aspect of the Presidency and what carries on with it after the President leaves office is taken away from him.
Now, Mr. Chief Justice, I suppose your suggestion was that there was an effect on the bill of attainder, because he has also been deprived of ownership of these papers.
I think that may very well be true.

In addition to that, he has been deprived of custody, of access, of any meaningful opportunity to have those documents in the way that former Presidents have, and the Archie Brown case also says that even preventive purposes, even entirely preventive purposes, are punishment within the meaning of the bill of attainder.
Thank you.

section.heading: Argument of Wade H. McCree, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Solicitor General?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

This appeal requires the Court to determine whether the Presidential Recordings and Material Preservation Act that provide for the impoundment and classification by officials of the Executive Branch of certain materials generated during the Administration of the former President and left by him temporarily in the White House following his resignation facially offends the Constitution.

We emphasis "facially", because the act became effective on December 19, 1974, and this action for a declaratory judgment and other relief was filed December 20th, before any action was taken under the statute.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, I think that the question as you put it, you could mean the entire act, is that the question, or is it legitimate to ask whether any section of it is facially unconstitutional?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I believe my answer to that, Mr. Justice White, is, the Appellant contends that the act is invalid in many respects; but our response is that there is a severability clause, and in the event this Court should find a provision of it invalid, it would not invalidate the entire legislation.

Appellant contends that the act violates the principle of the separation of powers, the prohibition against bills of attainder and his right to privacy and liberty of political expression and association.
The Government submits that the Congress acted constitutionally and that the judgment of the District Court should be affirmed.

As my brother has pointed out, the act requires the Administrator of General Services to take possession and complete control of the materials to prevent their destruction except as required by law; to make them available for use in any judicial proceeding or otherwise subject to legal process, subject to any rights, defenses or privileges that any one, including the former President, might raise.

The Act also requires the Administrator of General Services to afford former President Richard M. Nixon access at all times consistent with the Act and to afford access to the Executive Branch, and I stress Executive Branch, for lawful Government use.

And then, of course, it requires the issuance of regulations to prevent loss and destruction and ultimately to submit to the Congress regulations relating to public access, and I stress the distinction between the two sets of regulations, taking into account seven enumerated factors denominated as needs, which I suggest we need not discuss in detail, because these regulations had not been promulgated at the time of the attack on the statute was made, have not yet taken place, because they require Congressional acquiescence to become effective, and that acquiescence in the two efforts that were attempted was not forthcoming.
Finally, the act provides for the appropriation of money if a court should determine that a provision of the legislation should deprive an individual of private property without just compensation.

And so at this point I reiterate, since there are no regulations providing for public access and only regulations for safekeeping, which are not before the Court, as my brother indicated, and are not part of the record here, because indeed the Appellant has not claimed that they breach any rights of his.

We suggest respectfully that this Court should limit its inquiry to the face of the statute and should not be concerned with the many hypothetical horrors, as the District Court characterized them, that Appellant suggests might occur at some future time.

We suggest the proper time to consider these hobgoblins may be when the public-access regulations will have been promulgated and will have become effective, and there will have been decisions with respect to particular materials.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, I am not sure this bear directly; but do you think Congress can enact a statute impounding the papers of Federal judges generally or judges of one particular category or level, circuit judges, Supreme Court justices, or a particular Supreme Court or other judge or Justice?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I believe if the Congress apprehended some great harm to the republic, it could prevent the destruction of records in the custody of any public officer.
Now, there would be restrictions on its power to do it; but I would think the Congress would have that power to prevent the destruction of public records by any public custodian thereof.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What kind of a proceeding would be necessary to make that determination?
Presumably, your response indicates there would first be a finding or a determination.
By what process would the Congress make that?
I don't assume you mean it would be just to see Nixon and the Legislative Branch.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think the Congress, if the Court please, has the power and even the duty to protect Government property, and that is a specific charge that the Congress has set.

And I think the Congress, if it apprehends the destruction of public property, has the responsibility to provide for it; but it must provide for means adequate to protect the integrity of the branch of Government that is concerned, to protect personal rights, Executive privilege, judicial rights, judicial privileges.
But in response to the Chief Justice’s inquiry, yes, I think the Congress has the power to protect the papers from destruction.
Now, what it can do with it after that is quite a different matter.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: General McCree, do you think this case would stand on any different footing if a Congressional statute had been directed at Presidential papers that were located in Key Biscayne rather than the White House, where presumably the Government did not own the building they were located in, but the papers might be of the same general caliber?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I do not believe that would make any difference, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.

I believe if these are public papers, if they belong to the Government or if the Government has a substantial interest in them, and there was apprehension about their destruction before this can be ascertained, I think the Congress has that power.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is it necessary for you to sustain your proposition for us to find that the Government, in fact, owns the papers in question?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I submit it is not.
I think if the Government has a sufficient interest in them, the Government may have an interest that would require it to copy the papers.
I suggest to the Court that the papers might indicate material useful in the SALT talks that have just been recently pursued.

They might have information that would be necessary in matters of national security that the Executive Branch should have access to, and if these papers were in danger of destruction, I would think that Congress would have the power to provide for their protection until their contents could be made available to the appropriate persons.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You would not carry that over to papers in the hands of a private individual, I take it.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I do not believe I have to at this time, and I am not aware that the Congress has that power; but I just do not think I have to reach that question at this time, and I do not think this act does.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, Mr. Solicitor General, you do have to reach the question now of private papers.
You mentioned only public papers and Congress’ power over public papers.
Now, apparently no one suggested all the papers that have been seized here are public papers.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I concede, Mr. Justice White --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And let's just assume that as this Court read this statute, the statute would empower; they empower the regulator to withhold papers that anyone in his right mind would say are private papers.
Would you suggest that then that statute is unconstitutional on its face to that extent?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: On its face, if it instructed or authorized the impoundment of purely private papers, I would not be here to defend it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you know that that has been done already.
That has been done already, and the only question is, is there some adequate procedure to sort them out and return private papers?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If I may respond, the papers were comingled by the former President, and some method has to be employed to determine what papers are private and what papers are public or affected with such a public interest that they may be retained.
And a procedure has been established to classify it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.
Now, I will make my question very specific.

I would like to know where in the criteria that the regulator must use in preparing his regulations, where in those criteria is any assurance given that purely private papers will be returned to Mr. Nixon?
And even more precisely, suppose that someone like a regulator claims that this piece of paper, even though purely private, is of general historical interest.
Do you think those two categories are mutually exclusive?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think that it may be difficult to separate them; but if the Court please, Section 104 provides as the seventh of the enumerated needs on Page 4(a) of Appellant’s brief one finds that, that the regulations shall take into account among other things the need to give to Mr. Richard M. Nixon or his heirs for his sole custody and use tape recordings and other materials which are not likely to be related to the need described in the foregoing paragraphs, and so there is no intention.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Just finish the provision.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: And are not otherwise of general historical significance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, now, suppose Mr. Nixon has prepared a diary every day and put down exactly what he did, and let's suppose that someone thought that was a purely personal account.
Now, I can just imagine that someone might think it nevertheless is of general historical significance.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: May I refer the Court to need number five, the need to protect any party's opportunity to assert any legally or constitutionally based writer privilege which would prevent or otherwise limit access to such recordings and materials.

And I submit that this act affords Richard M. Nixon the opportunity to assert the contention that this diary of his is personal and has not the kind of general historical significance that will permit his deprivation, and that would then have to be adjudicated in a court; and ultimately, this Court will answer that question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, so you would agree, then, that 104 must be construed to sooner or later return to Mr. Nixon what we might call purely private papers.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Indeed, I do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Can you imagine any diary, thinking of Mr. Truman’s diary, which it was reported was a result of being dictated every evening after the day’s work, can you conceive of any such material that would not be of general historical interest?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I must concede being acquainted with some historians that it is difficult to conceive of anything that might not be of historical interest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Archivists and historians, like journalists, think that everything is historical.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Indeed, they are.

But this legislation recognizes that a claim of privacy, a claim of privilege, must be protected; and if the regulations are insufficient to do that, again, a court will have an opportunity to address itself to a particular item, such as a diary, before it can be turned over.
And for that reason, we suggest that the attack at this time is premature, because the statute, in recognizing the right of privacy, is facially adequate.

And the attack that was made the day after it became effective brought to this Court a marvelous opportunity to speculate about what might happen; but the regulations have not even been promulgated and acquiesced in so that they have become effective.
And this Court is asked to speculate about any number of horrors, as the court below --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The seizure has taken place, for want of a better …

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Rehnquist, it has, and it has been done for the purpose of safekeeping and preventing destruction; but the sorting and sifting has not even been begun.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And I take it from your answer to the Chief Justice’s question that Congress could immediately upon the retirement of Chief Justice Warren from this Court have passed a statute similar sequestering all the papers that he had in this building.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I believe it might for safekeeping, but it would have to set up reasons for doing it indicating why and provisions for returning to him everything that it could not appropriately take from him, and this statute purports to do that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why would it have to set up reasons for so doing?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I think I would like to reconsider my response.
I am not certain it would have to.
I am not certain it would have to except we assumed that the Congress acts because of a perceived need to act.
Now, it does not have to recite in the statute, if this is what Mr. Justice Blackmun is inquiring, why it so acted.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, are you saying you have emphasized the danger of destruction as an important justification, as I understand it, for this kind of legislation.

Are we to assume that Congress has made a finding of fact that there was a danger of destruction and that Mr. Nixon wan as unreliable custodian; and, if so, does that have any bearing on the bill of attainder?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, I would like to refer the Court to the House Committee report.
It's House of Representatives’ report on Page 3, where we find two significant items.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that in your brief, Mr. Solicitor General, or not?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I am not certain that this specific reference is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then, excuse me.
I have to ask for a citation on that.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If I just might be permitted to read the line.

In speaking of the agreement, which former President Nixon enacted with Mr. Sampson, the Administrator of General Services, which agreement was abrogated by this statute, thus the agreement gives Mr. Nixon total control over all the materials and records of his Administration.
It allows him to have access to the materials, but excludes others from reviewing these records.
Then by allowing Mr. Nixon to destroy all the materials, the agreement ignores the public interest in preserving them.
And so we have some evidence of Congressional abrogation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did that reference concern the problem of immediate destruction, or was that talking about destruction at a future date?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I am unable to differentiate it.
I must concede that it follows a paragraph that provides for the destruction of the tapes at a stated date, September 1, '79, or his death at a sooner date.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Certainly, that agreement did not contemplate the immediate destruction of any of these materials.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Except, if the Court please, it permitted him sole access and the opportunity --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In fact, it would seem to me that perhaps -- sole access; but you are saying this statute may be justified because of the danger of destruction, and it seems to me that agreement prevented the very danger that you are describing for a limited period of time and therefore would have permitted a careful deliberation of an appropriate statute applying to all Presidents.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, the Committee report contains this characterization of the agreement, and I quote again from Page 3: "This agreement would permit Mr. Nixon to remove and destroy any of these documents if he wishes to do so," and that certainly appears to evidence concern, apprehension, that it might indeed have.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn't that a statement of fact that would apply to every employee of the United States Government, from the President down to the lowliest doorkeeper, that it affords the opportunity?
Is that a finding of apprehension?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, coupled with historical facts, including the unexplained erasure of eighteen-and-a-half minutes of a taped recording, it would appear to be more than just a platter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did Congress recite that factor?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I am not aware that that recital appears in the Committee report; but reference is made to it in both briefs, and there is a record reference to it that I am not able to furnish at this time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, I do not know whether we can take judicial notice of the biographical writings of former Presidents or other public officials; but if we can, it is quite clear from what Mr. Lyndon Johnson wrote and what Harry Truman wrote that when they left the White House, they had with their own resources, plus the resources furnished by acts of Congress, a completely private screening under the exclusive control of the former President of all the papers to separate the personal from the truly public or even some of the historical matters.
And the biographical material of former Justices of this Court indicates that is generally the process they follow.

Do you see a difference exist between having that screening process under the sole control of the individual and the process provided by Congress; and, if so, whether there are any constitutional implications in the difference?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, there are similarities and differences, if the Court please.

The same people essentially are doing the screening as accomplished it under the Presidential libraries legislation, the Archival Section of the General Services Administration, and indeed this act provides that these archivists, who are professional persons, as the Court of course knows, with ethical standards to which to adhere and so forth, will also screen the material here, and I submit also it is within the same branch of Government; it is not outside the Executive Branch of Government.
So in that respect, it is the same.

The difference is, under the Presidential Libraries Act, previous Presidents have been permitted to, or no one has tried to stop them, have indeed established conditions concerning access to their papers provided for periods of time when they will be closed to everyone and provided various methods for access and release.

The Congress, though, over the years has passed a series of amendments to the Congressional Libraries Act until this really happens to be the last one in line, although it is not of general application.
But if the Court please …

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, before you move on, do you have any idea approximately as to how many archivists, secretaries, lawyers and other staff personnel have or will have access to these documents?
I think Mr. Miller mentioned 100 archivists.
Would it be 100?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: There is a statement in the record, and I regret, Mr. Justice Powell, that I cannot refer to it specifically.
I do not think the number is that high; but it could be when one considers that there are 42 million documents and 800 hours of tape.
But 100 sounds quite high, and I would just have to find that for the Court and furnish it to the Court.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: That number was identified in connection with the archivists.

A good many other personnel would see the papers, and I ask you a question that may sound frivolous; but do you think if 100 people know anything of great interest in the city of Washington that it will remain a secret?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Justice Powell, I have heard that if two people have heard it, it will not.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: You are probably right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, depending on the paper’s case, so to speak.
That is not two, but it's very few.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: But if the Court please, we submit that there is no violation of the principle of separation of powers.

Viewed on its face, as we suggest the statute must be viewed, instead of being an encroachment on powers reserved to the Executive Branch, the act entrusts the material to the custody of the Administrator of General Services, an Executive official appointed by the President and responsible to him; and so the suggestion that there would be any compromise of the integrity of the Executive Branch appears not to have force, because the person who will supervise the archivists who will do the classifications is responsible to the President.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, may I return for a moment to the question?
I did not really follow through enough on it about the question of danger of destruction.
I suppose there is always a possibility of destruction; if that is enough, why, then that would justify legislation of this kind with respect to any retiring official.

But we to take it that the view the Government is that the House Committee and the legislation is predicated on a finding that there was some abnormal danger of destruction that does not always exists with respect to any retiring official?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, may I refer the Court to the Government’s brief, the bottom of Page 50 and the top of Page 51, where there is a reference to specific House determinations of a specific fear.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solicitor General, I want to be sure you get the full import of my question.
I assume you could find support for the view that there is such a finding.
What I wanted to know is what the Government’s position is, because if you say the legislature made such a finding, that may undermine your position on the bill-of-attainder point.
It seems to me you must take a position one way or the other, and the position must be relevant to two arguments that your opponents make.
I am just curious on what your position is.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, the Government does not suggest that there must be such a finding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, my question is, does the Government suggest there was such a finding?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: The Government acknowledges that there was such a finding, but suggests that since no punishment was imposed or is imposed by the act that the prohibition against a bill of attainder is not violated.
That is our response to the attainder argument.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Can there be a violation of a protected interest by the impact of such a finding on a person’s reputation?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Indeed, there can be.
Indeed, there can be; but that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And would you take the view that this finding that you described has had no impact on this man’s reputation?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I certainly do not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then why is it not so?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Well, our understanding is that the prohibition against a bill of attainder is a prohibition against something more traditionally associated with punishment than injury to a person’s reputation.

In fact, we would submit that going through a Congressional investigation is not likely to assist a person in maintaining a good reputation; but no one suggests, I think, that that violates the attainder prohibition.
If the Court please, in the few minutes remaining, we would like to touch on one or two other matters.
We submit that facially the act does not invade the President’s right of privacy or any Executive privilege.

The act specifically provides that these are concerns with which the General Services Administrator is to be aware in the promulgation of his regulations and his determination of allowing access, public or private, to these papers; and the right of former President Nixon to assert these privileges is given to him by the statute, and we submit a court, perhaps this Court, will have to determine whether an asserted right exists and whether it must yield to an overriding interest, as it did in United States versus Nixon.
And so facially the Act protects these interests about which my brother expressed so much concern.

Finally, we suggest that the commingling of these papers was the act of the former President, and for him to suggest that the Fourth Amendment prevents the sifting of these papers to determine what are clearly his private papers and what are papers pertaining to matters in the public interest to which the Executive Branch should have access is something of his doing and that he should not be heard to complain about it.

The Fourth Amendment bars unreasonable searches, and the Government submits that the imperatives of national security and other aspects of the public interest make such an inspection eminently reasonable.
Professor Paul Frayne wrote: “History is a way of mocking those specters of disaster forecast from judicial decisions.”

The Government believes that so long as the courts retain their resourcefulness in applying precedents, their authority to reconsider doctrines in the light of the lessons of experience and the force of better reasoning, that the fears of irreparable harm which we have heard here today are likely to prove exaggerated.
We submit that on its face the statute is constitutional, and we respectfully submit that the judgment should be affirmed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: General McCree, the National Government is, of course, one of delegated powers, I suppose.
Which delegated power was Congress exercising, do you think, under its powers under Article I when it passed this legislation?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: There is a power -- I cannot give you the exact language -- to preserve and protect public property, and I certainly think that one, and I think the necessary and proper …

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would the power to preserve Government property depend on a finding by this Court that it was Government property?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Perhaps for some purpose.
As this Court has pointed out, the concept of property has many aspects.
Perhaps the Government might have an interest, not a propriety interest, but the kind of interest that would be entitled to the protection of the Congress.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: General McCree, you mentioned national defense as one of the justifications for the act.
Would you elaborate on that a bit?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, some of these papers may contain information furnished to the negotiators for our nation in the SALT talks.

Information perhaps concerning the number of nuclear submarines that we possess capable of launching subsurface missiles, these are matters that the ongoing Administration, whatever it is, must have access to if it is adequately to protect our security.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there one word in the record anywhere that suggests any danger that a former President of United States would destroy a record related to national defense?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: No.
If the Court please, the answer is, no, there is no word to that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You are not representing to this Court that there was any danger known to your office, also as far as the record is concerned known to the Congress, that documents pertaining to national defense would have been destroyed.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I am not suggesting that.

I can advise the Court that I am aware that there has been retrieval of certain documents of the type generally relating to national security from these papers since they have been in the custody of the Administrator of the General Services Administration; and with 42 million commingled documents, some method of retrieval must be established if a critical document is to be found within a time within which it can be useful to our nation.

And this also is provided for by the Act, access, and contrary to what my brother says, to members of any Department or Agency of the Executive Branch -- he neglected to emphasize that -- and there has been that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Excuse me for interrupting you.
How many Agencies and Departments are there in the Executive Branch, Mr. Solicitor General?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I do not have that figures at my fingertips, if the Court please; more that I think, I suspect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I suspect you are right.
And there are a couple of million people in the Executive Branch, I think.
But put that aside for the moment.
I have another question I would like to ask.

If you were a foreign diplomat and this Act is sustained, would you feel as free to divulge State secrets to the President of United States as you would have felt prior to the enactment to this statute?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I can honestly say that I would, because the statute mandates protecting any information relating to the nation’s security and any legal or constitutionally based rights or privileges, so I would expect Executive privilege to be protected from any unauthorized invasion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There will be at least several hundred people reading or listening to what the Ambassador of this country or that country said to the President of the United States.
Do you really think that that invasion would be kept confidential?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, my only response to that can be this.

The previous Presidents have taken their papers subject to no restrictions whatsoever, which means that an Ambassador would have to believe that anything that he spoke to another President might be discovered by persons not even under the restrictions that these responsible Government Archivists submit to.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But this is after this former President that you hypothesize has gone through the process of selecting and segregating, which each of the former Presidents, according to his own account, has done.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, the life of President John F. Kennedy terminated in office, and he did not have that privilege.
His estate, his executors, were the ones to make that decision, not having the sensitivity perhaps about some of these matters that the archivists might.
So it does not necessarily follow accordingly, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Solicitor General.

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Herzstein.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.

As you know, we are appearing on behalf of distinguished national organizations of historians, political scientists, reporters and various prominent members thereof, also a separate group of interveners, the Committee for Public Justice, and prominent members thereof, and a separate group for reporter Jack Anderson.
The national organizations include the American Historical Association and the American Political Science Association.

Now, I would like to make one thing very clear, and that is that there has been no question in this case raised by any of the interveners or the Government concerning Mr. Nixon’s entitlement to the return of his personal materials.
This includes diaries; it includes conversations with his family; any personal property of any kind not involving the actual transaction of Government business.
No issue of this sort was raised in the previous case before this statute was adopted.
The groups I represented brought suit against the Administrator to enjoin enforcement of the Nixon-Sampson Agreement.
In the very initial complaint that was filed in that case, it was made clear that all parties acknowledged the personal records should go back to Mr. Nixon.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But as a result of this legislation, there has been almost a three-year delay so far in his getting possession of what are entirely personal property, personally confidential documents and property.
The delay is not over yet.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Historical interest never will be given.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: May I address first the question of delay.
I think that has been very regrettable for us, also, Your Honor.

There has also been a delay in, of course, getting access to the Governmental materials that might otherwise have been made available for public access under normal circumstances; for instance, if these were treated as other Government materials.

The delay, I think, has been caused by the fact that the other litigation was well along and actually resulted into a decision by Judge Richey, but that was stayed in favor of the litigation concerning this statute.
So it is simply one of the costs of litigation, which we regret, too.
But there is just no question about the return of personal diaries, Dictabelts, so long as they are not the materials involved in the transaction of Government business.
Now, the statute, I agree, could have been drafted a little more clearly; but we think there are several points which make it quite clear that his personal materials are to be returned to him.
One is the fact that statute refers to the Presidential historical materials of Richard Nixon, not to the personal or private materials.
The second is that as Judge McCree mentioned, Criterion 7 calls for a return of materials to him.

And if you read those two in conjunction with the legislative history, there are statements on the floor of the Senate, on the floor of the House and in Committee reports indicating the expectation that Nixon’s personal records would be returned to him.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could you give us a capsule summary of the difference between what you have just referred to as Nixon’s personal records which will be returned and the matter which will not be returned?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Well, yes.
Certainly any personal letters among his family or friends, certainly a diary made at the end of the day as it were after the event.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even though the Dictabelt was paid for out of House White appropriations.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: That is right.
That does not bother us.

I think it is incidental now that we do have a different view on the tapes, which actually recorded the transaction of Government business by Government employees on Government time and so on, the normal tapes that we have all heard so much about.
The Dictabelts, Mr. Nixon has said, are his personal diary; instead of writing it down, in other words, he dictated it at the end of the day.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I want to be sure about that concession, because this is certainly is of historical interest.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: That is right, it is; but we do not feel it is not covered by the statute.
We have acknowledged that from the start.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is this concession shared by the Solicitor General, do you think?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: We believe it is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: About the fact that the paper belongs to the Government and so forth that we do not believe that makes a document a Government document; but beyond that, if the Court does --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about the Dictabelts representing his daily diary?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I would think that is a personal matter that should be returned to him once it was identified.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, is there any problem right this very minute of picking those up and giving them back to him?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: I know of no problem.
Whether it would have to await the adoption of a regulation which has been stymied by Mr. Nixon’s lawsuit, which has been delayed for three years --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, how has that stymied the issuance of regulations, Mr. Solicitor General?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: One of the dispositions of the District Court was to stay the effectiveness of regulations.
