Now, I think it held up principally the regulations for public access; the other regulations are not part of this record, and I cannot speak to the Court with any knowledge about them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that would not have prevented, would it, Mr. Solicitor General, for the development of regulations, the proposal and publication of all the regulations that were contemplated, would it, unless they have already done that and contemplate no other regulations?

turn.speaker: wade_h_mccree_jr
turn.label: Mr. Wade H. McCree, Jr.
turn.text: Of course, as the Court knows, two sets of regulations were sent to the Congress and were disapproved.
These were regulations for public access and not the 103 Regulations.
And the 103 Regulations are to assure the protection of the tape recordings and other materials and to prevent access by unauthorized persons and so forth.
So I just cannot answer that except to say that certainly the private diary should be returned.
No one would make any problem about that.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: May I say also on that point that we do not understand the regulations to be here under attack, including the Section 103 Regulations.
Mr. Nixon has not made any audible complaint as far as we have known about the fact that those regulations should have been redrafted.
He had an opportunity, I think, to litigate those, has had an opportunity and still does to litigate those Section 103 Regulations.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, there are not any 104 regulations, though, are there?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: No, no.
But the 103 Regulations are the ones which pertain to Mr. Nixon’s continuing access, which he is allowed to do right now.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you know what the present status is of the preparation of regulations for 104?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Well, it is a very long story.
I believe they have been submitted to Congress on two occasions, and certain portions were objected to the first time.
They came back, a certain smaller portion was objected at that time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you suggest that the Act becomes more suspect the longer it goes on without any provision whatsoever for implementing, sorting out and return?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Frankly, your Honor, I think the implementation of the regulations has been held up or at least has gone slower because this litigation is pending.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know that is what you keep saying.
But every now and then, you say that the Congress has disapproved the regulations.
So apparently, the litigation did not hold up the preparation of the regulations.
What has held it up, if the Congress had not disapproved them, they would long since has been issued.
How could the litigation have held them up?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: All I meant to say is that I am speculating that the General Services Administrator has been abiding the decision in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I will ask you again.
Suppose that goes on for ten years.
Does the Act become more suspect or not?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Of course it does, yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, there is nothing in Section 103 to authorize the return of the private diaries to Mr. Nixon.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: No except there is a problem of sorting. Mr. Nixon has objected to the Administrator going through and sorting, even, anything, and the courts at his request have enjoined any archival sorting of these materials at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But I suppose the scheme of the statute is that before any private material is returned, some third party must read the material to be sure it is private.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: That is right, that is the problem.
Since Mr. Nixon has not gone in and said, “Look, please sort out my Dictabelts and my personal diaries and so on and return them to me.”
He has gone in and said, “No, no one may see those things,” and he has asked the Court to enjoin that and we have not objected, no one has objected.
In other words, there has been a freeze on things at Mr. Nixon’s request pending this litigation.
Now, as I say, there is not really a dispute about the fact that Mr. Nixon should have back his personal papers.

The fact is, the dispute is caused by the fact that the personal records are a tiny fragment of this vast archive, which includes many papers of great public importance, importance both to the continuing needs of the Government, which is documented in the record quite amply and in the decision of the court below, and the needs of --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Herzstein, can I ask one other question about the vast quantity of material?
Some of that material was Watergate-related, I suppose, and that was that material which was most likely to be destroyed, I suppose, if we were to read the Congressional material.
Is there any evidence of a danger of destruction of anything other than Watergate-related material?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: There is not that I know of, Your Honor.
I would have to check through the legislative history on that and see.
I think there certainly is evidence of a lack of confidence that the de facto practice that has existed in the case of past Presidents perhaps might not work so well this time.
I think that appears amply --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is there any such evidence respecting anything except material related to Watergate?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Not that I know of, Your Honor.
There has been a need for access to, I think, some 25 boxes of the material since Mr. Nixon left office for national-security purposes.
That came out at a deposition of the Secretary of the National Security Council.
In other words, the Ford Administration has had to go in there and use some of these things.
Now, whether they would have been able to do it as well or as readily if they were in Mr. Nixon’s possession is, of course, hard to say.
There is also evidence in the record, however, of difficulties in past Administrations giving access to national-security material of prior Administrations.
And I think this is quite apart from Watergate.
There was a justification for Congress to say, “Look, the Presidency is important nowadays.
It generates vast amounts of material which the President never sees which are needed for the Government.
It is time that we continue this evolution that has been going on since the days of Hoover, Presidential Libraries and so on.
It is time we continue this and set up an orderly regime, which takes these materials and puts them into Government custody.
We think that there is no problem about the power of Congress to do that.
The only problem in this case is caused by the intermingling that occurred with some of Mr. Nixon’s records during his Administration.

And the problems Mr. Nixon is raising concerning Executive privilege and concerning privacy really come down to the question of how do we segregate these things, protecting the interests of both sides.
Basically, his position is, because a small fragment of my materials are in there, I should be able to take the whole thing, and it should be my sole judgment what is personal and what is public.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How do we know it is a small fragment that is personal?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Your Honor, Mr. Nixon testified that out of the 42 million in his deposition in this case, he could not have seen possibly more 200,000 during his Administration, and of course most of those 200,000 that he saw would have been in the course of Government business; so that that means only a small fragment of that would be personal.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, his claim of Executive privilege, by which I take it you mean his separation-of-powers claim, basically is not premised at all upon the fact that these are personal papers, but almost the opposite: that they are Presidential official papers.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: I think that is right, basically he has two points.
As to the privacy, he is saying they are personal; as to the Executive privilege, he is saying, “The Presidency will founder unless I can do this.”

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, not necessarily founder, but at least it would impair the protection of separation of powers as found in our Constitution.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Yes, that is right.

I think that basically what we face here on that question, separation of powers, is a situation in which the incumbent Executive, both the Ford Administration and the Carter Administration, are satisfied that there is no impairment of Executive powers.
Congress is satisfied, so we have two branches of the Government entirely satisfied -- in fact, aiming at working out these problems of continuity of Government in a certain way.

Mr. Nixon, a person who is no longer in the Government, who no longer is subject to public accountability, is seeking the assistance of this Court to intercede with the Executive Branch and tell the Executive Branch the way it is planning on handling Executive Branch records with concurrence of Congress as a separation of powers.
We believe, Your Honor, that it is a violation of the separation of powers to do what Mr. Nixon is requesting.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you share the view that Congress could constitutionally provide that on the termination of office of any Federal judge or a Justice that all of his papers then located in any public building or under his control relating to his tenure of office could be impounded until the archivists had decided which were the personal items and which were those relating to the decision-making process?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: We believe, Your Honor -- and needless to say, this case is not before us, but we have given attention to that; we addressed it in our brief -- we believe that there is quite apart from the segregation, there is certainly a basis for distinguishing judicial records from Executive Branch records.
There may be even grave doubt as to the power of Congress to say that the unpublished records of members of the Judicial Branch are subject to Congressional power.

The reason I say that, without meaning to show any lack of reverence to the Court is that I think, frankly, the public interest in having access to the unpublished records of the Court is simply not nearly as great as that relating to the President.
The President is part of a political process.
The effectiveness of his regime and the legitimacy of what he does depends on his following procedures that are designed to maximize public information about what he is doing.
The Court is insulated from the political process.
Everything the Court does is on the public record already.
The materials that it can use in reaching its decision are only those on the record, and the decisions it reaches are on the record.
In the case of the President, because he is a part of a political process and because of his vast powers, he can draw on any information he wants.
It is not on the public record when he uses it, and many of the decisions he makes are never on the public record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So are you suggesting that we limit ourselves to the briefs when we reach a decision on the case and the record?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Yes, I am, your Honor.
I hope that is not a contempt of court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean that these oral arguments are useless?

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Well, no.
This is part of the public record, too, I assume.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not necessarily.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: I saw some recorders here this morning.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The tape recording is not necessarily part of any public record.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Oh, no; but, of course, the public is attending.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I just wanted to be sure you were not denigrating the oral arguments.

turn.speaker: robert_e_herzstein
turn.label: Mr. Robert E. Herzstein
turn.text: Are there are any further questions, Your Honor?

section.heading: Rebuttal of Herbert J. Miller, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Thank you.
Mr. Miller, do you have anything further?
You have about nine or ten minutes left.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: If I may, Your Honor, I would like address myself to try to clear one factor up before we go any further.
Of 42 million papers which may be involved in the Presidential material …

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By the way, how does anybody know how many there are?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: It is an estimate, if the Court please.
I do not know that there is a …

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where does it come from?
Whose estimate is that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I believe probably the GSA made the estimate, if the Court please; but I am not really, really certain about that.
But my point is, you cannot ignore the vast substantial quantity of personal and private conversations and records in this case, because overall there may be 42 million documents.
We are talking about five-and-one-half years of a man’s private life.
So you cannot ignore and say there is nothing involved so far as the person is concerned, because they may only be 5% or 10% of the large --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Miller, have you made any effort to get the personal papers back?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: We have filed a lawsuit, which is not this lawsuit, before Judge Richey, requesting that the Government of the United States comply with the obligation that it entered into by contract, whereby all of these documents would be shipped to a Government installation in California not far from Mr. Nixon’s home; that they would be placed under strict safeguards pursuant to the contract; that there would be two keys for access --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, my question was, did you ask specifically, not all the documents, but that the personal documents be given to him?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I do not recall if that was specifically covered, but I do recall in oral argument before Judge Richey pointing out that the personal documents were not being turned over and pointing out how unfair this was.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This was not under this Act, was it?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, during this, have you ever asked since this Act was passed?
Have you ever asked that the personal property be returned?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I have never specifically asked that the personal property be returned, but I have asked --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then, doesn't that cut into your argument by saying that all of this has involved personal property?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court please, when we filed a complaint in this case on December 20th, the day after the Act went into effect, we challenged the constitutionality, and as a part of that complaint we requested that the documents be returned.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All of the documents.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, it would include the property.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But did you ever specifically say you want the Dictabelts back?
Did you ever say that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I do not recall specifically asking for the Dictabelts back.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did you ever say, "We want the personal documents, then we will litigate the others"?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: As a part of the return of the documents, all of the documents, yes, specifically, the complaints did ask for the return of the personal documents.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your complaint alleged that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I believe you will find that in the Complaint that was filed December 20th.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I will go look at it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, it would be inconsistent in a way for you to ask for anything less than all of them, because one of your constitutional complaints is that you do not want Government agents, dozens or maybe a hundred, rummaging through these things.
That is one of your constitutional challenges.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
That is precisely right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To decide what is personal or what is not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is precisely why you asked for your own man to go in there and pick them out?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir.
The reason is is because the statute prohibited it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you believe the Court would have given them that, despite this Act?.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No.
No, it cannot.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Oh, you do not think the Court could enjoin that part of the statute.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I do not think it is possible.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not until the sorting-out process has been completed.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No.

And furthermore, if the Court please, with respect to the tape recordings themselves, we have to remember that there are two provisions of this particular statute: 101(a), which applies directly to the tape recordings, and that is a severable, distinct and separate section from Section 101(b), which seizes all of the other material.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Miller, I think Mr. Herzstein suggested that of the 42 million total, there are about 200,000 or less that would qualify as personal documents.
Is that right?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: That is what Mr. Herzstein said.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you agree with that?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No, I do not.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You think there are more than 200,000?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: I think there are more than 200,000.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In the category of the Dictabelts and other personal letters and things?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I do.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what does the record suggest?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: The record shows that when Mr. Nixon was asked during his deposition how many documents he had seen in the course of his function as President of the United States, he finally estimated approximately 200,000.

The record further shows … but that has no relationship whatsoever to the tapes, which are 5,000 hours of conversation, and the evidence and the record show that he talked to his wife or his daughter one or maybe several times a day.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And recorded those, also?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: And that these were recorded; that he had discussions with his lawyers, with his friends; he discussed political matters as the head of the political party.
All of these political personal matters are on these tapes, and there is no limitation in the statute that these tapes are, quote, “Presidential material”.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do you think if it suggests anything, the records shows as to how many would fall into what you would define as personal as against what otherwise would be official?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: There is no way to make a proper estimate of the number of papers that are personal.

You take the record, which shows that Mr. Nixon resided in the White House for five-and-a-half years; that there are some 800 reels of tape that covered not only the Oval Office, the EOB office, but also the telephone in the residential part of the White House.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Incidentally, do the 42 million include, as Brother Rehnquist suggested earlier … what about papers or whatever they may constitute at San Clemente or in Florida?
Do these 42 million items include any of those, or are we talking only about White House?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: The 42 million, I do not know whether it would include those or not.

The statute, as the Court will recall, empowers the Administrator of General Services to take steps to retrieve any Presidential materials which are not at the White House, which include those of San Clemente.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, has that been done?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: No, it has not, because the implementation of the statute was in effect staved when we filed our lawsuit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I suggest that the 42 million are only White House-originated documents, then.

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: White House, and frankly maybe 20 million of those are Government publications, anniversary greetings, birthday greetings.
I mean, they have no bearing whatsoever on this lawsuit.

But we are talking here the guts of this lawsuit are the tapes and the Presidential discussions and decision-making process and the political aspect of the President of the United States for a five-and-a-half-year period.
I mean, this 42 million papers is nothing, is make-believe.
It has no bearing on this case whatsoever.

What we are talking about is a man’s life for five-and-a-half years, acting as President of the United States, meeting with his associates and his subordinates, obtaining advice from them, meeting with foreign officials, determining the conduct of the foreign policy of the United States, talking with his wife, talking with his daughter the day before she was married, and what discussions were recorded.
But these are the sum and substance of what we talking about.
It is not 42 million documents.

That is a figure that should not even be as a part of a record in terms of what the gut issues of this case are, because we are talking about a gross violation of the Fourth Amendment that will take effect forthwith, because the Section 102(b) gives access to Agencies or Departments of the United States; they can review these records.
And let me disabuse the Court if I may of one thing, and that is the commingling argument.
Those records were commingled, because for 200 years the Presidents of the United States had a right to expect the right to control in the privacy of their papers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Miller, before you sit down, I would like to ask you the same question I asked your opponent.
Do you construe the legislative history as being tantamount to a finding that Mr. Nixon was an unreliable custodian?

turn.speaker: herbert_j_miller_jr
turn.label: Mr. Herbert J. Miller, Jr.
turn.text: Listening to the argument of my esteemed opponent, that is the only basis upon which you can justify the legislation that there was such a finding and that such a finding, existing as it does, turns this Act into a bill of attainder.
That is our argument.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
